title: BIOLOGY 101: The Fundamentals of Cell Biology
summary: This lecture introduces the cell as the fundamental "unit of life" for all organisms, detailing its essential characteristics: metabolism, growth, response to environment, homeostasis, and genetic material. It distinctly categorizes cells into two main types: simpler prokaryotic cells (lacking a true nucleus, like bacteria) and more complex eukaryotic cells (possessing a true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles, like animal and plant cells). Key cellular components discussed include the protective cell membrane, the cytoplasm, and, in eukaryotes, the nucleus and mitochondria, which generate energy.
key_points: The cell is the basic unit of organization and life, performing all necessary functions for living organisms.
Cells exhibit key characteristics: metabolism, growth/reproduction, response to environment, homeostasis, and containing genetic material (DNA).
Life is fundamentally divided into two cell types: prokaryotic (simpler, no true nucleus) and eukaryotic (complex, true nucleus and membrane-bound organelles).
Basic cellular structures include the cell membrane (for protection and selective permeability), cytoplasm, and in eukaryotes, the nucleus (genetic control) and mitochondria (energy production).

definitions.definition: The smallest unit of life that can function independently and perform all the necessary functions of life; a membrane-bound compartment containing genetic material (DNA) and cytoplasm.
The ability of cells to maintain a stable internal environment despite changes in the external environment.
Simple, primitive cells lacking a membrane-bound nucleus, with their genetic material located in a region called the nucleoid, typically found in bacteria and archaea.
More complex cells characterized by the presence of a true membrane-bound nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles, found in animals, plants, fungi, and protists.

examples: Single-celled bacterium (as a basic unit of life)
E. coli (as an example of a prokaryotic cell)
Chicken egg cell (as an example of a macroscopic cell)
Animals, plants, fungi, and protists (as organisms made of eukaryotic cells)
exam_pointers: Memorize the five key characteristics that define a cell as 'alive' (Metabolism, Growth/Reproduction, Response, Homeostasis, Genetic Material).
Be able to clearly distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells based on the presence of a nucleus, membrane-bound organelles, and typical size.
Recall the primary functions of the cell membrane: protection, selective permeability, communication, and recognition.
Identify mitochondria as the 'powerhouses' of the cell, responsible for producing ATP (energy).
